author: Chris Greenberg
title: Morning Sports Update: Cowboys coach scolds Greg Hardy after Gisele, gun remarks - Sports
text:
The backlash to Greg Hardy’s comments about Gisele continues, a Bruins star took an illegal hit in their opener and more trouble for the daily fantasy industry.
Advertisement - Continue Reading Below Cowboys coach Jason Garrett scolds Greg Hardy: “Well, we just addressed it immediately,” Garrett said Thursday. “That’s not how we want to operate as an organization. Players and coaches in our organization understand that. We want to distinguish ourselves with our play, not with what we say.” [ USA Today ]
FanDuel, DraftKings face class action lawsuit for insider trading: “Fantasy football player Adam Johnson sued both sites Thursday in Manhattan Federal Court. Johnson alleges that participants in both sites’ daily games were unfairly disadvantaged by employees of each company being allowed to play the other’s game. The daily, salary-based team-assembly games at DraftKings and Fanduel are highly similar in concept.” [ SI.com ]
Bruins coach Claude Julien thinks Winnipeg’s Burmistrov deserves further punishment for hit on Bergeron: “Burmistrov dropped Bergeron with a high elbow late in the first period of Boston’s season-opening loss. The Jets center was whistled for an illegal check to the head, and Bergeron and Winnipeg winger Adam Lowry each were given two minutes for roughing in the scrum that ensued.” [ NESN.com ]
Former Red Sox teammates Jon Lester and John Lackey to face off in MLB playoffs: “Lack is one of my better friends in baseball, better friends in life, I love his family, I love him,” Lester said. “But come Friday, we’re not friends anymore. He’ll say the same thing. I love Lack, he’s one of the best competitors I’ve ever gotten to play with, ever gotten to be around.” [ St. Louis Post-Dispatch ]
Watch former BU standout Jack Eichel score a goal in his NHL debut: “It was a special moment. It’s something I’ll never forget.” [ Boston.com ]
Cowboys’ Jeremy Mincey explains the Patriots as a cheeseburger: “It’s a little different,” Mincey said of playing in New England. “Secret sauce, I mean shoot, they just do everything high in details pretty much like what we’ve been doing. Got a lot of great leadership. Then on top of that, secret sauce is Tom Brady. You take him off it’s like taking cheese off a cheeseburger. You see what I’m saying? So he is the secret sauce.” [ ESPN.com ]
Remember when they tore down the Boston Garden?
Previous -- of -- Next The old Boston Garden opened on November 17, 1928 as the “Boston Madison Square Garden.” Shortened not long after its opening to to just “Boston Garden,” the venue served as host to some of the greatest moments on Boston history, and it was demolished in 1998 in the shadow of its replacement: the Fleet Center. Globe File Photo Previous -- of -- Next The Boston Garden officially closed its doors in 1995, and the venue remained vacant for three years. The last official event held in the old Garden was fittingly an exhibition game between the Bruins and Montreal Canadiens. Globe File Photo Previous -- of -- Next The Boston Garden was a revered building, but it certainly had its flaws— the largest one being its lack of air conditioning. The Green Machine raised 16 championship banners in the old building, they and boasted amazing players such as the original “Big Three”: Robert Parish, Larry Bird, and Kevin McHale. Globe File Photo Previous -- of -- Next But it also hosted significant cultural events, such as Senator John F. Kennedy’s huge rally in his final day of campaigning for the Presidency of the United States on November 7, 1960. Globe File Photo Previous -- of -- Next An eleveted platform on Causeway Street is taken down in 1995 in preparation for the demolition. Globe File Photo Previous -- of -- Next Former professional boxer Tommy Rawson, Jr. poses in 1998 where the boxing ring was located on the floor of the old Garden. The Boston native fought in the Boxing Carnival Extravaganza when the Boston Garden first opened in 1928. Rawson passed away in 2003 at the age of 94. AP File Photo Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next The most famous hockey moment in Boston Garden history came courtesy of a diving Bobby Orr, which became a Stanley Cup-winning goal over the St. Louis Blues in 1970. Globe File Photo Previous -- of -- Next In music history, the Boston Garden played host to The Beatles during the band’s first tour of the United States. The quartet from Liverpool played to an at-capacity crowd of 13,909 on September 12, 1964. Globe File Photo Previous -- of -- Next It was an emotional time for many when the old Boston Garden was reduced to a pile of rubble. Here, construction worker Ed Sullivan snaps a photo during his lunch break to capture a moment in history. The building will forever live on as a cultural icon in the rich history of Boston.
